awd_titl_txt: Autism-Related Characteristics in College STEM Students: Prevalence, Performance, and Mediation
awd_abstract_narration:
Each year, roughly 49,000 individuals diagnosed with autism complete high school. Approximately 16,000 of them subsequently pursue higher education, with about 1 in 3 autistic college students seeking a degree in the STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) fields. Historically, however, people on the autism spectrum have had poor postsecondary and employment outcomes. Yet the very traits that can cause students with autism-related characteristics to struggle in college classrooms may also serve as a springboard from which this population can make distinctive contributions to STEM fields and workplaces. This project will highlight the potential of autistic college students, increase awareness of the prevalence of autism in college classrooms, and provide tools to shape both institutional policy and instructional practices in ways that facilitate success for students with autism-related characteristics. 

Although students on the autism spectrum may be particularly well-suited for success in STEM fields due to their ability to observe, identify, construct, and apply logical systems of reasoning, college students with autism are often reluctant to disclose their diagnosis or seek formal disability accommodations. As a result, these students are typically an "invisible" minority on campus. To address these issues, this project will seek to (1) determine the prevalence of autism-related characteristics among college students entering STEM fields; (2) assess the effect of autism-related characteristics on student performance in gateway STEM courses; and (3) evaluate the effect of formal disability accommodations on the classroom performance of STEM students with autism-related characteristics. The study, thus, examines the possibility that an already existing but underutilized intervention could serve as a low-cost, high-yield mechanism to help autistic students leverage their unique characteristics to complete their STEM degrees, enter the workforce, and contribute to the national economy.

por.por_cntn:
College students with autism and its associated characteristics (e.g., intense focus on specific topics, pattern recognition and application) may be particularly well-suited to succeed in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. Such autism-related characteristics (ARCs) align with the skills and mindsets traditionally valued in these fields. This project explored linkages between these ARCs and students’ enrollment in STEM majors and a variety of postsecondary outcomes - including student grades in gateway STEM courses, persistence within the institution, and completion of a bachelor’s degree. It also examined whether registration with the university’s disability service office moderated the effect of ARCs on those outcomes. The study yields three overarching results.


First, there is limited evidence indicative of a small tendency for the STEM fields to attract students with slightly higher levels of autism-related characteristics. Second, any relationship between ARCs and student persistence appears confined to the first year of college. Third, all other results suggest an overall lack of association between ARCs and student outcomes. There was no clear or convincing evidence to conclude that the presence of more ARCs was directly related to students’ overall GPA or grades in STEM gateway courses, nor that registration for disability accomodations moderated any effects of autism-related characteristics.


Collectively, these findings suggest that autism or its related characteristics need not be viewed as inherent deficits that undermine students’ chances for postsecondary success. Neither does it seem likely that an infusion of autistic students into higher education will serve as a panacea to address the ongoing shortage of qualified STEM professionals. Instead, the study suggests that students with autism and their related characteristics are just as likely as their neurotypical peers to make contributions to filling that gap.
